Award.AwardTitle: New Earth-Abundant Metal Complexes for CO2 Conversion and Reduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
While many view carbon dioxide (CO2) as a waste gas, there exist efforts in many laboratories to use CO2 as a building block and C1 synthon to produce more complex organic molecules. Most of these ongoing studies utilize rare and expensive late-transition metal complexes as catalysts. In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) section of NSF's Division of Chemistry, Professor Richard Kemp of the University of New Mexico and his students are examining the fundamental reactions of earth-abundant main group and transition metals to reduce CO2 to more valuable, small organic molecules via electrocatalysis. The long-term goal is to eventually use a renewable source of electrons (such as wind or solar derived) to re-energize CO2 back into transportation fuel precursors. If successful, the funded efforts will help lead to a closed carbon loop that allows recycle of CO2 back into transportation fuels for re-use.

While the primary work outputs of this grant will be the trained students and postdoctoral fellows and the published scientific results they generate, the broader impacts of this project extend into environmental chemistry, public policy debate, and the greenhouse gas reduction issue, with long-term implications in the transportation sector as fossil fuels continue to be depleted. UNM is a minority/Hispanic-serving university, and the PI's group has a long-standing history of educating students from under-represented groups, and aiding their entry into STEM careers. This tradition is expected to continue during this current funding period, and the interactions between UNM and overseas partners in third world countries will be further expanded.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our team’s research effort while working on CHE12-13529 has been geared towards understanding the preparation, characterization, and fundamental chemistry of CO2-containing complexes that contain earth abundant metals. Our major focus has been on the main group metals that involve s and p orbitals in their binding to CO2, with limited efforts directed toward the more commonly-used, inexpensive d-block transition metals, primarily first row and similar metals.  During this grant period we have shown the formation of a novel interaction between CO2 and these main group precursor complexes that we have termed “adducts”.  These adducts bind CO2 in a cooperative fashion in that the precursor metal/ligand complex has both Lewis acid/Lewis base sites to coordinate to the amphoteric CO2 molecule.  While this concept is not entirely novel as it builds upon the "frustrated Lewis pair" concept described by Stephan/Erker, we have shown that, importantly and surprisingly, in our work the Lewis acids do not have to be highly acidic nor do the Lewis bases have to extremely bulky.  Accordingly, our complexes are not “frustrated” as seen by others; yet, these complexes are still capable of activating small molecules.  Our working hypothesis is that these adducts now contain bent CO2 – in X-ray crystallography studies we see that the CO2 fragment itself is no longer linear but bent to approximately 130 degrees.  It is our belief that this conversion to a bent structure upon coordination is a key structural feature that allows the CO2 to be reduced to other organic molecules via a facilitated, lower-energy pathway.  The energy needed to overcome bending CO2 from linear to 130 degrees, which is required for producing other organic molecules from CO2, has now been provided by the dual acid/base nature of our adducts.  Interestingly, our CO2 adducts can be bound extremely tightly, extremely transiently and loosely, or most ideally for us – strong enough to bind CO2 and to characterize the adduct, but not so strongly that the metal complex will not release the products. Selected scientific highlights begin with the synthesis and full characterization of a number of these CO2-metal adducts using a variety of metals by a number of analytical techniques.  During the past three years, we have shown that we can electrocatalytically reduce CO2 to CO using an inexpensive Zn-complex in place of expensive Pt-metal at much lower potentials than previously seen, thus validating our hypothesis that bent CO2-complexes will allow more facile reduction.  We have prepared CO2-containing complexes from ~10 different metals, leading us to understand many of the factors that govern these reactions. We have also shown differences in reactivity with our substituted P-N-P ligands, and this knowledge will be useful to a variety of outside groups. Our papers report the fundamental structural and reactivity changes that occur, depending on which substituents are used.      

 

Our research group believes that our obligation in taxpayer-funded research projects is that we owe to the public at a minimum two work products – not only the advances in basic science mentioned above but also opportunities and education in human resources. This second product – the training, mentoring, and education of the students who are funded by NSF – is just as critical to the overall success of the project as are the papers we publish.  At the University of New Mexico (UNM), our group has a long and well-documented history of attracting, welcoming, and providing educational opportunities for a number of female students/postdoctoral fellows as well as undergraduate and graduate students from traditionally under-represented groups.  UNM is a minority/Hispanic-serving university and we are fortunate to attract many of the best and brightest of these students. During the past funding period a total of 13 students, including PDFs (3), graduate (2), undergraduate (5), and high school students (3), have been fully or partially-supported in their education and training by NSF.  Of these 13 students, 5 are female and 3 are members of under-represented groups.  We note that all of these students/postdoctoral fellows have been co-authors on submitted or published manuscripts and/or presentations at outside meetings.  The postdoctoral fellows and the senior graduate students have had ample opportunities to develop their mentoring skills towards younger students under the careful direction of the PI. These mentoring skills will be invaluable to these students as they pursue careers in academia, national laboratories, and industry.  Our research group is located at the Advanced Materials Laboratory, a facility jointly managed by UNM and Sandia National Laboratories. Every year, our entire group participates in K-5 outreach programs in which we teach the concepts of the scientific method and nanotechnology basics to 300+ elementary school age students from New Mexico. These youngsters come from all corners of the state to participate in this program, and the PI’s group is fortunate to be highly-involved in the planning and implementation of this outreach activity.
